_prev_prog_3.CT_OtherType: FSM Workshops and corporate training conference
_prev_prog_3.Description:
PREVENTION PROGRAM DESCRIPTION



The Americold hazardous material release Prevention Program in place for compliance with 40 CFR 68 RMP is based on the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard 29 CFR 1910.119 in conjunction with industry guidelines of the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration, IIAR. The first element in the safe function of ammonia refrigeration equipment is in the design itself.  All components in the refrigeration system are designed and installed in compliance with the industry standards of ANSI/IIAR ASHRAE, ASME and jurisdictional codes in effect at the time of construction.  In order for this system to function safely and effectively over a long period of time, maintenance and inspections are conducted on a scheduled basis to assure system integrity and functional efficiency. Maintenance and system monitoring is accomplished by employees that are trained to follow safe work procedures when operating the equipment. Also built into the system are automated engineered safeguards that continually monitor the operating equipment to maintain pressures, temperatures, liquid levels and detection of accidental releases.  In the event of a system upset, warning systems are in place 24/7 to alert operators of operational deviations before they become emergencies.



Operator training is among the most important elements of the release prevention program.  Initially the prevention program began with the gathering of equipment information and employee involvement in the process hazard analysis PHA study.  The PHA methodology used for the study is the hazards and operability (Hazop) study.  The PHA team used this method to identify whether hazards exist and then identify the actions necessary to correct them.   Other areas of training include development of operating and maintenance procedures and safe work practices, process safety compliance audits, emergency response hands-on practice in mock spill drills and the use of personal protection equipment.   



Operators receive emergency responder training in order to understand how to evaluate and manage emergency situations safely and effectively.  Release prevention begins with mitigating even the smallest of leaks that occur operationally.  These are take very seriously to avoid failures that contribute to more serious releases.  Lock-out/tag-out, pump out procedures and line opening,  procedures are very important for preventing further hazards when making even minor repairs on the system.  Employees in general also receive training for ammonia awareness for knowledge of ammonia hazards, exposure prevention and what to do in the event exposure would occur.   The emergency procedures established for the facility includes and emergency action and fire prevention  plan. 

For continued improvement of the release prevention plan, internal safety audits are conducted that include reviews of safe work procedures, siting evaluations and recommendations for any deficiencies identified that affect the safety of the ammonia refrigeration process.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



RISK MANAGEMENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The following information provided describes the executive summary for Americold Zumbrota, Minnesota risk management release prevention program to comply with the requirements of the EPA's 40 CFR Part 68.155- Executive Summary.  The RMP release prevention program for this facility is in conjunction with the OSHA 1910.119 process safety management program.  The hazard assessment for this process identifies potential off site consequences related to an accidental release of the chemical, anhydrous ammonia that is contained in the process.  A program management system is also in place at the facility that details the lines of authority for overall responsibility of this risk management plan and maintenance of the release prevention program. 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE PREPAREDNESS

The Americold Zumbrota, Minnesota (Plant 2305) facility abides by the emergency procedures of OSHA 1910.38 emergency action plan. However hazwoper 1910.120 applies to this facility in the event of a chemical accident that requires emergency response.  The emergency response plan is coordinated with the Zumbrota Fire Department through which Goodhue County has mutual aid established with Minnesota Homeland Security District 1 hazmat response located in Rochester Minnesota.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives: 



To save lives.

To minimize off site impacts and avoid injuries.

To protect the environment.

To minimize property damage.



AmeriCold maintains a safety committee and has employees designated as coordinators for the facility that are identified in the Americold emergency action plan.   The Facility Service Manager and Plant Manager are responsible for the process safety and the emergency planning for off site consequences that are primary objectives of the risk management program. The emergency plan includes the instructions for notifications, safe evacuation and miti

gation procedures to handle small releases.  To respond effectively in emergency situations involving a chemical release, trained refrigeration employees are on call locally 24/7.  The emergency plan is reviewed and updated when necessary and at least annually.  This Plan is in place to ensure the neighboring community, environment and the safety of the employees is addressed in order to sustain compliance with regulatory requirements to provide a safe work place.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The AmeriCold Zumbrota facility is a public refrigerated warehouse.  Its standard industrial classification is SIC 4222.  The North American industrial classification system designation is NAICS 49312.  This facility stores and distributes a variety of refrigerated food products for its customers. The refrigeration process, consisting of piping, valves, vessels, air units and compressor equipment utilizes anhydrous ammonia, a natural refrigerant for the industrial refrigeration system. Changes in pressure through the refrigeration cycle relate directly to changes in temperature of the refrigerant. For example, lowering the pressure of a refrigerant lowers its temperature. Low pressure, (cold) The ammonia refrigerant absorbs heat through storage room air units.  Removal of the heat from the room provides the refrigeration affect.  Removal of ambient heat from products in turn reduces the spoilage and allows for extended storage of food products.

Anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7664-41-7) Refrigerant grade, pure anhydrous ammonia is the chemical in the process.  In low concentrations ammonia is easily detectable and has a pungent odor that makes it ideal as a refrigerant because of this self alarming characteristic. 

The ammonia inventory at the Americold Zumbrota facility is above the Threshold Planning Quantity of 10,000 lbs.  Ammonia is listed and reportable as an extremely hazardous substance, an EHS on the SARA Title III list of lists.  Due to

the volume of ammonia in the process this facility, compliance is required under the clean air act section CAA 112r, RMP- Accidental Release Prevention Program, and OSHA 1910.119 PSM. The process meets the criteria of program 3 for purposes of managing compliance.  Due to the ammonia that is present this facility also abides by section 302, 304, 311, and 312 of the emergency planning community right to know act-EPCRA.  



CHEMICAL SPECIFIC AMMONIA RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



To assure safety, maintenance of the process is in accordance with industry standards and best practices.  Americold corporate policies and procedures designed to assure that best practices are followed are incorporated into the release prevention program.  Americold Zumbrota adheres to the guidelines of the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR).  The standards and guidelines include the following but are not limited to:



IIAR Ammonia Data Book                                                                                                       IIAR Bulletin 107, "Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When Making Ammonia Refrigeration Tie-ins"

IIAR Bulletin 109, "Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe Ammonia Refrigeration System"

IIAR Bulletin R1, "A Guide to Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia Refrigeration System"



In conjunction with the RMP release prevention program, the OSHA 1910.119 PSM program is adopted as the culture in which this facility manages its compliance for the prevention program elements of the EPA Risk Management Program.  

The release prevention program integrates the elements of process safety management that includes, employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training, contractor qualifications, pre start up review, mechanical integrity, hot work, management of change, incident investigation, emergency planning, compliance audits.  This process has no trade secrets to disclos

e as confidential business information.  

Of these elements the process hazard analysis (PHA) study aims at preventing deviations in the process equipment in order to prevent it from operating outside of its original design intent.  The PHA teams aim is to identify hazards within the process and develop solutions that prevent accidental releases, prevent injuries and environmental damage.  The study focuses on local administrative and engineering controls that make improvements for safer operation of the process.  PHA recommendations receive careful consideration, especially when improved safety for the process is achievable. 

Mechanical integrity inspections and scheduled preventive maintenance are in place to maintain process equipment.  This program is another line of defense to prevent deviations that potentially would result in an accidental release of ammonia.  Recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices are adhered to and followed to maintain the process equipment in safe operating condition.  



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no releases of ammonia reported to the National Response Center, state and local jurisdiction in the last 5 years that met the RMP reportable release criteria from this facility.  



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The AmeriCold Zumbrota facility has an Emergency Action Plan in place according to the requirements of 1910.38 along with a fire prevention plan.  Emergency response for the facility is coordinated with Zumbrota Fire Department and the state Homeland Security emergency management District 1.  The facility service manager responsible for the refrigeration process is trained to respond and to assist the local fire department hazmat team during an emergency.  The hazmat technician employees receive 8 hour refresher training on an annual basis.  Emergency response team members receive occupational screening, medical evaluations, and are fit tested for the proper use of respiratory protection.  



Th

e facility conducts annual evacuation drills to ensure all employees understand the emergency evacuation, and shelter in place procedures for different types of emergencies that can occur.  In addition, the Zumbrota Fire Department tours the facility annually for compliance with jurisdictional fire safety requirements.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Americold has dedicated resources specifically to address safety compliance related capital projects identified at its ammonia facilities.  Training for Facility Service Managers is arranged organization wide for compliance with safety and environmental requirements.   The Process Hazard Analysis, hazards and operability study (HAZOP) and the PSM compliance audit during the generate recommendations to improve safety at the AmeriCold Zumbrota facility located at 1000 Arctic Ave.  PHA action items are risk ranked for criticality and addressed in a prioritized fashion.  Upgrades targeted as improvement projects include safety relief valve system design and relief valve calculations.  Additional emergency ventilation for the machinery room with additional ammonia detection and alarm coverage in equipment areas.
